Keep this color in mind and in your arsenal!

colors.name: Cold Water
colors.manufacturer_description: Boro Batch wants you to beat the heat with the refreshing Cold Water! Cold Water is a transparent light blue. Expand your color palette and quench your artistic thirst with Cold Water!

colors.name: Peafowl Test #28
colors.manufacturer_description: Peafowl Test #28 is a semi opaque blue green

colors.name: Beryl Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 660833 Glass Alchemy Beryl Borosilicate Glass Rods. Beryl was designed as an organic color to fill a huge hole in the borosilicate palette. A color that is seen (but not often noticed) in nature and called retro by those that recall the oil lamps and cruets of the 60's, Beryl makes a great bead color, is useful as a tint or sculptural color. This brownish olive green is wonderful for solid color sculpting and works very nicely for blown work as well. For larger blown work, artist Mike Shelbo recommends sandwiching between a clear tube and another layer of clear or transparent color, reason being is that Beryl is made up of a significant amount of copper. When a heavy copper color is not encased and on the surface for blown work that will be melted, blown, and manipulated it will tend to react with different amounts of propane and oxygen in your flame mix. So where Beryl may feel similar to working clear, it will prefer working about halfway to three quarters of the flame length away from the tip of your torch is an even mix of gas. Working Tip : Work in a neutral flame to avoid reduction (red streaks). Also available as a frit.

colors.name: Brozay Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 668672 Glass Alchemy Brozay Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Cobalt 6 Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 660516 Glass Alchemy Cobalt 6 Borosilicate Glass Rods. Cobalt-6 was one of Glass Alchemy's early releases. The darkest of the Glass Alchemy cobalt colors we were faced with "how dark is too dark?" We had the millifiori maker and the stringer puller in mind when we developed this color. Now one of our most popular colors, it is used by many anytime they need a denser darker color. When drawn down to extremely thin threads, it will still remain a deep cobalt blue transparent. Keep Cobalt-6 in the outer region of your flame length, in a mix of gas that will not reduce the color if used without encasement. Grey streaks or patches could develop from too much propane in your torch flame, so using a neutral flame is best. Working Tip : Work in a neutral flame to avoid reduction. Also available as a frit.

colors.name: Sienna Brown Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 660864 Glass Alchemy Sienna Brown Borosilicate Glass Rods. Sienna Brown was one of Glass Alchemy's first six colors. An elegant brown created to fit in to the mostly transparent palette at the time, this color easily falls in to several color schemes. It becomes deeper in tone, approaching black as it is melted into larger gathers. Sienna is a cinnamon brown that can be controlled by thickness of color application. When drawing down in to stringers you can encase solid clear or color with Sienna and achieve a very light tint or in blown application get an extremely subtle tint by sandwiching in clear and blowing thin. Working Tip : Work in a neutral flame to avoid reduction (black and gray wisps). Also available as a frit.

colors.name: Tonic Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 660490 Glass Alchemy Tonic Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Orange
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Orange is a bright transparent striking orange that is well suited for sculpture, bead work, and moderately thin blown work. The striking process is temperature related but in order to prevent any muddying, work in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. It is recommended to kiln strike Northstar Orange. Northstar Orange looks great over Northstar Star White, and be sure to try layering Northstar Amber/Purple over it.

colors.name: Opaque Aqua
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Opaque Aqua is a very nice opal blue green color. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. Northstar Opaque Aqua will enhance your art because it has a really nice appearance and color. It is not susceptible to reduction and is not flame sensitive. For best results, keep in a neutral flame.

colors.name: Ninja
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Ninja is a smooth moderately dense blue based black. It is well suited for sculptural applications and blown work. It is creamy and works easily, making it a welcomed addition to the palette of blacks from which to choose. When working Northstar Ninja, do so in an oxidizing flame. In a reductive environment it will develop grey streaks on the surface and result in a dull matte finish. When applying the color, do so gently. After it is melted it can take a lot of heat. Northstar Ninja is great in combination with many colors and serves as a background for striking colors. Be sure to try layering your favorite Amber/Purple over the surface.

colors.name: Nile
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Nile is a unique organic version of our Northstar Amber/Purple. It yields rich earthy tones and burnt amber hues. It is well suited for blown and sculptural applications, but it is not saturated enough for thin stringer applications. It is also useful as an overlay color. When working Nile, use a hot oxidizing flame. It can be flame or kiln struck to yield a rich "glazed pottery-like" finish. It is also interesting to note that when this color is coiled, the coil lines are virtually unnoticeable and it yields a truly uniform surface. Be sure to try it over your favorite opaque!

colors.name: Nemo
colors.manufacturer_description: Nemo is a vibrant aqua marine blue that is flame stable and nearly air free. The goal with this color is to minimize the livering effect caused by copper in the glass being exposed to a reducing atmosphere of a propane rich flame. This glass has a highly refractive and beautiful gem like aquamarine hue.

colors.name: Mint
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Mint is a semi opaque bright green that is great as a background color. It is easy to work and atmospherically stable, meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being affected. If stretched too thin it will lose intensity so it is not recommended for stringer applications. Mint looks great with a thin coating of Northstar Multi or Northstar Transparent Green.

colors.name: Midnight
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Midnight is a deep opaque blue. It is great for stringers and thin cane work and can be stretched out far! It is heat and flame sensitive. It must be warmed up slowly and once glowing, heat gently. Because the color is so intense it must be worked in an oxidizing flame. If the flame is not oxidizing enough, the color will develop grayish brown streaks.

colors.name: Maple Syrup
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar has reached back into the history books for this color to meet the demand by artists for new and exciting transparent colors. Originally discontinued from their boro color palette as NS-42 Cinnamon, they have brought back this transparent brown with a reformulation to decrease air content and homogenize the color. This glass is from "Abe's Vault"!

colors.name: Luna (UV fluorescent)
colors.manufacturer_description: Luna is a clear glass that fluoresces blue under a U.V. light source. Northstar recommends using an ultraviolet L.E.D. flashlight with a 365Nm-395Nm range for the brightest blue glow. No uranium is used in this glass.

colors.name: Lokis Lipstick
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Lokis Lipstick is a silver striking color. It is a close companion to Northstar Amber/Purple but with a little more control of the color strike. Work Lokis Lipstick in an oxidizing flame to achieve the most vivid color range. It can be struck in the torch or in the kiln. You can achieve colors that look like gold and silver fume as well as deep purples. If reduced enough, it will yield creamy yellows and whites. Lokis Lipstick works well in all applications. It is quickly becoming a must in the artists palette.

colors.name: Loch Ness
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Loch Ness is dark opaque, sparkly dark green that can be used in virtually any application. Best if worked in a neutral to oxidizing flame to achieve optimum results. Extended annealing tends to brings out a golden hue in this color.

colors.name: Light Blue Amber Purple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Light Blue Amber/Purple is the least saturated of the five Amber/Purple colors Northstar produces. It yields a light purplish blue strike. Work in a hot neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Reduction will affect the strike. Light Blue Amber/Purple is not well suited for thin blown work but best suited for sculptural applications. Light Blue Amber/Purple looks great over Northstar Star White and Northstar Blue Caramel.

colors.name: Lavender
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Lavender is a transparent light bluish purple. It is atmospherically stable meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being changed. It is also resistant to excessive heat, and can take a lot of abuse. Because Lavender washes out when thinned, most think of it as a color used for sculpture only. However, like the other transparent colors, Lavender is well suited as an overlay color. Try layering it over your favorite Exotic or Amber/Purple.

colors.name: Jet Black
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Jet Black is a very dense black. It is well suited for sculptural applications and blown work. It is creamy and works easily, making it a welcome addition to the palette of blacks from which to choose. When working Northstar Jet Black, do so in an oxidizing flame. If worked in a reductive environment it will develop gray streaks on the surface and result in a dull matte finish. When applying the color, do so gently. After it is melted in it can take a lot of heat. Jet Black is great in combination with many colors and serves as a great background for striking colors.

colors.name: Irrid
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Irrid is the least saturated of the transparent striking colors. When oxidized, it produces a silvery transparent metallic blue. When reduced, Northstar Irrid turns a light sea green color. Irrid can be worked hot and is another forgiving striking color. Try layering it over an opaque to yield new effects.

colors.name: Indigo Aventurine
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Indigo Aventurine is a fully opaque deep night blue aventurine color. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is easily worked and can take a lot of heat. To keep the color most vibrant, work in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. It looks great over Northstar Star White and be sure to try encasing it with Northstar Ice Blue!

colors.name: Ice Blue
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Ice Blue is a lush copper blue that has an unrivaled eye catching appeal. It is a light transparent color but it adds great optical depth, even in thin layers. It is not suitable for stringers or cane work, but it is great for sculpture and blown work. It's effects as an overlay color are impressive. When added over Northstar Blue Moon, it produces a very appealing blue. To keep Ice Blue from dulling or discoloring, work in an oxidizing flame. If worked in a neutral to reducing flame the color will darken and develop reddish brown striations in the body of the glass.

colors.name: Hydra (multi-chromatic)
colors.manufacturer_description: Hydra is simply a beautiful light transparent icy green. As a multi-chromatic color, this glass will shift depending on light source and kelvin temperature of the light bulb. this color will present a beautiful green, light blue, and even a very light purple. For best results, use a 2700K (kelvin) CFL bulb as well as using this glass in thicker applications. This glass contains a small amount of copper, use an oxidizing flame for best results.

colors.name: Hyacinth
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Hyacinth is a lush fully opaque faux purple. It is great for blown work and thin stringer application. It is heat and flame sensitive so it must be heated up slowly to prevent boiling. Once it glows red, Hyacinth will take heat well. Because of it's intensity, it is sensitive to reduction. If the flame is not oxidizing enough, gray and brown streaks will develop on the surface of the glass. Try it with a layer of Northstar Violet for a deep purple effect.

colors.name: Grizzly
colors.manufacturer_description: Grizzly is an opaque brown. this glass holds a dense earthen brown which works well in sculptural and blown applications. As a cadmium based color, the working characteristics will be similar to Cherry or Lava. Grizzly is heat sensitive so it must be worked carefully to prevent boiling. Encasing with clear is another method to shielding the color, but not necessary.

colors.name: Green Transparent
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Transparent Green is a transparent emerald green. It is intense enough for blown work and looks great in sculpture. Northstar Transparent Green is sensitive to atmosphere and in order to maintain it's original color, work in an oxidizing flame. If worked in a reducing flame, Northstar Transparent Green will develop brick red streaks. Try layering Transparent Green over Northstar Forest Green or Northstar Green Exotic for exciting effects.

colors.name: Green Amber Purple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Green Amber/Purple is the most intense and exciting of the Northstar Amber/Purple family. It reacts quickly and produces the lushest purplish blue strike. It can range in color from a pale silvery blue to an opaque to a sea green all the way to a cloudy grey. It is well suited for flame striking and produces wonderful results. Because it is so intense, be sure to keep a hot oxidizing flame set. Reduction will affect the strike. Try it over Northstar Star White. Another excellent combination is Northstar Orange hobnails over the surface of Green Amber/Purple. There is a lot you can do with this color so have fun exploring!

colors.name: Glacier Blue
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Glacier Blue is a darker version of Northstar Ice Blue. It has a green tint to the color and like Northstar Ice Blue; Glacier adds great optical depth, even in thin layers. It is not suitable for stringers or cane work, but it is great for sculpture and blown work. It's effects as an overlay color are impressive. Try this color over Northstar Periwinkle or Northstar Skyline for great color effects. As like Northstar Ice Blue, Glacier is also sensitive to a reductive flame. Because it is more saturated, extra care has to be taken to prevent reduction from developing. By using a strong oxidizing flame, no reddish brown streaks will develop.

colors.name: Garnet
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Garnet is a member of the self striking ruby family. Garnet is the medium intensity shade of the three shades of self striking rubies Northstar currently offers. It is best suited for medium thickness blown work and highlights. The self striking rubies are the next generation of colors offering the user cleaner, purer colors with less air and difficulty in working. When using Northstar Garnet, do so in a neutral to oxidizing flame. Once hot, Garnet will turn transparent just as the standard Northstar rubies, but as it cools it turns a uniform ruby red. The strike is easily repeatable and the final color is not affected by kilning. Even after numerous reheats no livering will occur. Note that the final shade of red is darker than the initial color of the rod. Once heated and allowed to strike, the final color can be viewed. After prolonged use in sculptural and inside out applications, Northstar Garnet can develop a deep brown hue. This can usually be reversed by heating the color until molten. For a great color effect, try layering Garnet of Northstar Poppy.

colors.name: Garnet Dark
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Garnet Dark is the most saturated self striking Ruby Northstar currently offers. It is best suited for thin stringer, thin blown work, and lip wrap. The self striking rubies are the next generation of colors offering the user cleaner, purer colors with less air and difficulty in working. When working Northstar Garnet Dark use a hot oxidizing flame. Once hot, Garnet Dark will turn transparent just as the standard Northstar rubies, but as it cools it turns a uniform ruby red. The strike is easily repeatable and the final color is not affected by kilning. Even after numerous reheats no livering will occur. Note that the final shade of red is darker than the initial color of the rod. Once heated and allowed to strike, the final color can be viewed. After prolonged use in sculptural and inside out applications, Northstar Garnet Dark can develop a deep brown hue. This can usually be reversed by heating the color until molten.

colors.name: Forest Green
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Forest Green is a very saturated, fully opaque green that just might be the most versatile green on the market today. It can be worked in any flame without fear of discoloration. It is recommended to stay in a neutral flame. It works well for encased applications. It is great for stringer applications and thin blown work. For a neat effect, try layering Northstar Multi over Northstar Forest Green.

colors.name: Extra Light Yellow
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Extra Light Yellow is a diluted version of Northstar Yellow. It can be worked in virtually any flame without the color being affected. It is great for sculpture and as an overlay. By adding Extra Light Yellow over opaque colors a bluish hazy glow is added to the piece. Try is over Northstar Turbo Cobalt!

colors.name: Experimental Green #5
colors.manufacturer_description: When working Northstar Experimental Green #5 you can achieve many different colors. When used in an oxidizing flame the color will stay a very vivid neon emerald green. Use in a less hot flame to achieve an opaque blue similar to Northstar Blue Moon. Experimental Green #5 can also shift to a creamy white and lime green. Experimental Green #5 needs to be tried as it is hard to explain.

colors.name: Exotic Red
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Exotic Red: The Exotic family contains the most saturated striking colors in the Northstar family. Northstar Exotic Red produces and deep metallic burgundy. To keep the Exotics most vibrant, work is a super oxidizing environment until you are finished with the piece. Then, turn the flame down and bathe the piece in a super reducing flame for several seconds to produce the mirror like sheen. Another great effect that is possible with the Exotics is encasement with clear. This group of colors can be stretched out and is great for blown work. If heavily encased, be sure to anneal thoroughly. Exotics are also enhanced by backing with Northstar Star White. Northstar Exotic Red differs from the rest in that kiln striking will amplify the red qualities. Try layering Northstar Pink over Red Exotic.

colors.name: Exotic Green
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Exotic Green: The Exotic family contains the most saturated striking colors in the Northstar family. Northstar Green Exotic can yield a mirror like green metallic finish and if over-reduced a very organic earthy tone as well. To keep the Exotics most vibrant, work in a super oxidizing environment until you are finished with the piece. Then, turn the flame down and bathe the piece in a super reducing flame for several seconds to produce the mirror like sheen. Another great effect that is possible with the Exotics is encasement with clear. This group of colors can be stretched out and is great for blown work. If heavily encased, be sure to anneal thoroughly. Exotics are also enhanced by backing with Northstar Star White.

colors.name: Exotic Blue
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Blue Exotic: The Exotic family contains the most saturated striking colors in the Northstar family. Northstar Blue Exotic can yield a mirror like blue metallic finish and if over-reduced a very organic earthy tone as well. To keep the Exotics most vibrant, work in a super oxidizing environment until you are finished with the piece. Then, turn the flame down and bathe the piece in a super reducing flame for several seconds to produce the mirror like sheen. Another great effect that is possible with the Exotics is encasement with clear. This group of colors can be stretched out and is great for blown work. If heavily encased, be sure to anneal thoroughly. Exotics are also enhanced by backing with Northstar Star White. Try layering Northstar Yellow over Northstar Blue Exotic.

colors.name: Evergreen
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Evergreen is more dark than it's Northstar Forest Green counterpart, Evergreen is smooth and creamy. A neutral flame is the best when working this color but can be worked in practically any flame without fear of discoloration. It works well for encased applications. It is great for stringer applications and thin blown work. Try using it next to Northstar Forest Green and Northstar Jade for a beautiful green fade.

colors.name: Egyptian White Sand
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Egyptian White Sand is a rich opaque color reminiscent of elephant ivory or the bleached carved hieroglyphic tablets excavated from ancient Egypt. It is not sensitive to flame chemistry but must be worked in soft gentle heat to prevent surface scarring or boiling. Once worked, the color can be heated more rapidly and take a larger volume of heat. The key is working the color slowly until it is melted in smooth. It is a formulation based on Northstar Star White but on that offers even greater opacity and intensity. Northstar Egyptian White Sand's antiqued color and grainy texture is ideal for shading in sculptural applications such as murrini cane, while it's intensity allows for it's application in extremely thin blown work. It is also an ideal background color.

colors.name: Double Amber Purple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Double Amber/Purple is the more intense version of Northstar Amber/Purple. It produces the most exciting metallic purples and vermilion. It behaves similarly in the flame as regular Amber/Purple but because of it's greater intensity more care has to be taken to prevent reduction. Double Amber/Purple can be stretched further and can be blown relatively thin without losing the vibrant purple strike. Be sure to try layering Double Amber/Purple over Northstar Blue Caramel.

colors.name: Deep Blue Sea Glass
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Deep Sea Blue is a fully opaque saturated blue. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. For those of you searching for a substitute for Northstar Polaris, this is the closest color to it. It is not susceptible to reduction and is not flame sensitive. For best results keep in a neutral flame. It is a great backing for such colors as Northstar Irrid and Northstar Turquesa, and goes well with Northstar Canary.

colors.name: Dark Ruby
colors.manufacturer_description: The most saturated of the transparent striking Rubies. Work in an oxidizing flame. Designed primarily for flame striking, but can be kilned as well.

colors.name: Dark Orange
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Dark Orange is a more saturated version of Northstar Orange. It is well suited for thin blown work, cane work, or when a deep semi-opaque orange is desired.

colors.name: Dark Multi
colors.manufacturer_description: Dark Multi is the more intense version of Northstar's Multi and will yield similar effects, but much more pronounced.

colors.name: Dark Cobalt Blue
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Dark Cobalt is the second most saturated of the four shades of cobalt blue Northstar produces. Dark Cobalt is well suited for thin blown work and cane work. Because of it's intensity it must be worked in an oxidizing flame to prevent graying.

colors.name: Dark Blue Amber Purple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Dark Blue Amber/Purple is the more intense version of Light Blue Amber/Purple. It yields a more intense semi opaque strike and has more blue tint. Due to it's intensity, it is useful for thin blown work and cane applications. Work Dark Blue Amber/Purple in a hot neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Reduction will affect the strike. Dark Blue Amber/Purple's strike is amplified by a backing of Northstar Star White.

colors.name: Dark Amethyst
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Dark Amethyst is a light transparent violet color. This is a "what you see is what you get" color. Use in a slightly neutral to oxidizing flame for best results. Northstar Dark Amethyst works like butter so do not hesitate to spread it over other colors. The color looks best in solid color blowouts and sculpture work. Stringers tend to lose color and may appear as a clear Violet.

colors.name: Crystal Bliss
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Crystal Bliss is a light cobalt blue with lots of sparkle. The color is not heat sensitive and works great. Northstar Crystal Bliss is very light in color and when pulled thin, the color will fade to clear. We created Crystal Bliss for the artists who like to coat their colors with sparkle. Use an oxidizing flame to cut down on red lines of copper.

colors.name: Cherry
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Cherry is the most eye-catching member of the opaque family. It is a bright candy apple red that is well suited for stringer application and blown work. Cherry is slightly sensitive to reduction, so work in a soft neutral flame. However, Cherry is heat sensitive so it must be worked carefully to prevent boiling. Encasing with clear is another method of shielding the color, but not necessary. Cherry can be easily worked on the surface and will not boil or scar if worked carefully in a soft flame. A nice color effect is to try is a layer of Northstar Rootbeer over Northstar Cherry.

colors.name: Caramel
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Caramel is a more intense version of Northstar Butterscotch. It is a rich silvery tan color that can be stretched out thin. It is great for stringer application and blown work. Work in a neutral to oxidizing flame for bright tan colors. To bring out the silvery mirror like sheen, bathe the piece in a reducing flame. Be sure to try Northstar Ruby or Northstar Amber/Purple over Northstar Caramel.

colors.name: Butterscotch
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Butterscotch is a semi opaque buttery tan color. It can yield rich purplish blue tones and silver hues. When kept in a more oxidizing environment more of the blues and purples will appear. If reduced, a silvery haze will appear on the surface. Butterscotch is easy to work and can take a lot of heat, making it a forgiving striking color. It can be stretched out and is good for blown work and sculpture. If you are looking for something even more intense, try Northstar Caramel.

colors.name: Brillo
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Brillo is a beautiful steel grey transparent sparkle that can be used by itself or mixed with any color to add sparkle, try layering Brillo over other colors to add sparkle. We recommend using an oxidizing flame setting to cut down on boiling. Layer Brillo over Northstar Pink or Northstar Pomegranate for some great effects!

colors.name: Blue Thunder
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Blue Thunder is a dark cobalt blue color with silver. When worked in an oxidizing flame, Blue Thunder yields bright metallic blues. When worked in a neutral flame it yields bright hazy greens. When worked in a heavily reducing flame Blue Thunder produces a nice ash gray. It is well suited for stringer application, blown work, and sculpture. Northstar Blue Thunder is a lighter version of Northstar Blue Moon with the same working values.

colors.name: Blue Moon
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Blue Moon is a favorite striking color in the Northstar palette. When worked in an oxidizing flame, Blue Moon yields bright metallic blues. When worked in a neutral flame it yields bright hazy greens. When worked in a heavily reduced flame, Blue Moon produces a nice ash gray. It is well suited for stringer application, blown work, and sculpture. Be sure to try encasing Northstar Blue Moon with clear or Northstar Yellow for great effects.

colors.name: Blue Green
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Blue Green is the more saturated version of Northstar Turquesa. It is a vibrant striking semi opaque blue. When oxidized, Blue Green yields a rich smokey blue strike. When worked in a neutral environment, Northstar Blue Green produces bright metallic greens. When reduced, this color produces hazy gray tones. It looks great when cased with clear and try layering Northstar Orange over the surface. To make the strike even more vibrant, back Northstar Blue Green with Northstar Star White.

colors.name: Black Lightning
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Black Lightning is a very dense black with silver. Northstar Black Lightning can yield a mirror like blue metallic finish or if over-reduced an organic earthy tone. To keep Northstar Black Lightning most vibrant, work in a super oxidizing environment until you are finished with the piece. Then, turn the flame down and bathe the piece in a super reducing flame for several seconds to produce the mirror like sheen. For another great effect, encase Black Lightning with clear. This color can be stretched out and is great for blown work. If heavily encased, be sure to anneal thoroughly. This is the bigger brother of Northstar Alaskan Thunder.

colors.name: Berry Gumbolt
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Berry Gumbolt is a fully opaque saturated dark blue. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is not susceptible to reduction and is not flame sensitive. For best results, keep it in a neutral flame. It is a great backing color for such colors as Northstar Irrid and Northstar Turquesa, and goes well with Northstar Canary.

colors.name: Alaskan Thunder
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Alaskan Thunder is a black blue silver color. When worked in an oxidizing flame, Northstar Alaskan Thunder yields bright metallic blues, greens, and purples. When worked in a neutral flame it yields bright hazy green, white, and cream colors. When worked in a heavily reducing flame, Northstar Alaskan Thunder produces a nice ash gray. It is well suited for stringer application, blown work, and sculpture. Try encasing Northstar Alaskan Thunder with clear or Northstar Yellow for great effects.

colors.name: Absinthe
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Absinthe was developed to meet the demand by artists for new and exciting transparent colors. This glass will present similar working characteristics as Sublime with a stronger emerald green color. This color will thin out if used in stringer form but will hold a gem quality vibrant green that is unaffected by flame chemistry when worked in more solid applications.

colors.name: Ghost
colors.manufacturer_description: Ghost is Northstar’s newest addition to the permanent palette and is a part of our newest line of colors, “the Future Line”. Made from batch in Portland, OR and formulated with the easy working characteristics of Secret White and air free quality of Opaline to achieve a highly workable and smooth opalescent white. Our intent with this experiment is to supply artists with best material at affordable cost. Safe for deep encasements and works great in all flame atmospheres.

colors.name: Lucy Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Lucy is clear with very few inclusions, and when worked it remains quite clear in normal lighting. Under UV lighting Lucy is a very intense hot pink. A very stable color to add to the UV palette. Lucy works great on the surface and can also be worked under clear. Fantastic for blown and sculpted applications. A recommended use is layering and blending it with other colors for a neat effect!

colors.name: Peach
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Peach is a bright transparent golden color that is another member of the transparent family. Peach is an excellent color for sculpture. It is easy to work, and is atmospherically stable (meaning is can be worked in any flame without the color changing.) Another great use for Northstar Peach is use as an overlay color, as with any other transparent color. Northstar Peach looks great over Northstar Double Amber/Purple as well as Northstar Caramel.

colors.name: Pink
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Pink is a light transparent bright pink. It is atmospherically stable meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being changed. It is also resistant to excessive heat, and can take a lot of abuse. Because Northstar Pink washes out when thinned, most regard this color as one solely for sculpture. Surprisingly another great role for Northstar Pink and other transparent colors is use as overlay colors. Northstar Pink looks great over Northstar Double Amber/Purple, Northstar Blue Moon, and many others. By using a thin coating of pink, a striking color can be transformed into an entirely new shade.

colors.name: Plum Krazy
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Plum Krazy is a dark transparent faux purple that strikes to a rich smokey blue. Work in a cool oxidizing flame to prevent overheating and striking the color. When ready to strike, either kiln at 1050*F or bathe the glass in a gentle bushy neutral flame to bring out the soft blue strike. This color is best suited for moderately thick coil-potted work and sculptural applications. When encased in clear this color produces a vibrant violet with wisps of metallic blue. Be sure to try it over Northstar Star White or Northstar Blue Caramel. Prolonged reduction leads to a grayish blue opaque surface.

colors.name: Plum Kush
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Plum Kush is a black sparkle. It is well suited for sculptural applications and blown work. It is creamy and works easily. When working Plum Kush, do so in an oxidizing flame. A reductive environment will cause grey streaks to develop on the surface and result in a dull matte finish. When applying the color, do so gently. After it is melted in, it can take a lot of heat. This is the first black sparkle introduced to colored borosilicate palette and is a welcome addition to the palette of blacks from which to choose.

colors.name: Pomegranate
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Pomegranate is the lightest shade of the self striking rubies Northstar currently offers. It is designed specifically for sculptural work and think blown work, allowing for a clear unlivered ruby to be achieved. The self striking rubies are the next generation of colors offering the user cleaner, purer colors with less air and difficulty in working. When working Northstar Pomegranate, do so in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Once hot, Pomegranate will turn transparent just as the standard Northstar rubies, but as it cools and depending on thickness, will strike back to red. Because this color is so unsaturated, the final strike must take place in the kiln. The strike is easily repeatable and the final color is not affected by soaking in the kiln for long periods of time. Even after numerous reheats no livering will occur. In addition, Northstar Pomegranate will not develop any brown hues as with the case of the other two members of the striking ruby family. Note that the final shade of red is darker than the initial color of the rod. Once heated and allowed to strike, the final color can be viewed.

colors.name: Poppy
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Poppy is the most eye catching, saturated, and easy working member of the intense opaque family. It is a deep Halloween orange great for stringer applications and thin blown work. It is hardly sensitive to flame chemistry, but it must be worked carefully to prevent boiling. Encasing with clear is another method to shielding the color, but not necessary. Poppy can be easily worked on the surface and will not boil or scar if worked carefully in a soft flame. For a nice color effect layer Northstar Ruby over the surface of Poppy.

colors.name: Purple Urple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Purple Urple is a dark purple that looks like Northstar Hyacinth but works differently in the flame. This opaque purple uses chrome technology but does not have cracking problems. It is great for blown work and thin stringer application. It is heat and flame sensitive so it must be heated up slowly to prevent boiling. Once it glows red, Northstar Purple Urple will take heat well. Because of it's intensity, it is sensitive to reduction. If the flame is not oxidizing enough, gray and brown streaks will develop on the surface of the glass. Try it with a layer of Northstar Violet for a deep purple effect.

colors.name: Rootbeer
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Rootbeer is a striking red that can yield numerous effects ranging from rich blues and purples to reds and earthy browns. Rootbeer is well suited for sculpture and blown work of all thickness. It can be kiln or flame struck. It strikes more quickly than any other striking reds, so plan carefully. Work in a neutral to oxidizing flame to keep it from developing any liveriness. Try backing it with Northstar Cherry. It also looks great cased with Northstar Amber/Purple.

colors.name: Ruby Slippers
colors.manufacturer_description: Exp. #155 is a transparent sparkly red named “Ruby Slippers” after the old school version Northstar made over 15 years ago! This newest formula uses a NS-88 Pomegranate base red with a TAG Stardust sparkle. With little to no air content, this glass is easy to use in all flame atmospheres. As a kiln striking red, it’s recommended to strike for 6-8 hours at 1050° F. This color is a great option for overlays and color combos! Note: The sparkle is hard to capture in photos and looks best in natural sunlight!

colors.name: Silver Amethyst
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Silver Amethyst is a dark violet color with silver. Work in a cool oxidizing flame to prevent overheating and striking the color.

colors.name: Silver Aqua
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Steel Wool is a unique addition to the borosilicate color palette. It is a funky, bumpy color rod that turns smooth when melted. It has tons of sparkle and can be mixed with any color to add a sparkly shimmer to any piece. Steel Wool can be used in all applications with no cracking issues but use caution in deep encasement. We recommend using a neutral/oxidizing flame for Steel Wool. Use in the back of the flame and try a reducing flame to cut down on boiling. Try mixing Northstar Dark Cobalt with Northstar Steel Wool to get a very nice blue sparkle. A little hand mixing of Steel Wool will give you the color you desire.

colors.name: Silver Bullet
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Silver Bullet is a look alike of Northstar Caramel. It is a rich silvery tan color that can be stretched out thin. It is great for stringer application and blown work. Work in a hot neutral to oxidizing flame for bright tan colors. To bring out the silvery mirror like sheen, bathe the piece in a reducing flame. Try Northstar Ruby or Northstar Amber/Purple over Silver Bullet.

colors.name: Silver Creek
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Silver Creek is a silver based color which produces the most exciting metallic purples and vermilions as well as silvery greens and blues. It is a very stable color. It behaves similarly in the flame as Northstar Amber/Purple and Northstar Double Amber/Purple, but because of it's greater core range, more care has to be taken to prevent reduction and boiling. Northstar Silver Creek can be stretched and can be blown relatively thin without losing the vibrant colors. Try using with other colors to achieve multi layered color combination.

colors.name: Silver Seaweed
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Silver Sea Weed is a funky green color. It is a wild silver striker that can take a lot of heat and be used in many different applications. Working in an oxidizing flame will yield intense purple hues that are like Northern Lights. If reduced, this color will will inherit wispy cream colors with a tint of green.

colors.name: Silver Unobtainium
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Silver Unobtainium is also a dark blue sparkle that has silver in it. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is easily worked and can take a lot of heat. To keep the color most vibrant, work in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Try to avoid deep encasement that may cause cracking. When worked in an oxidizing flame Silver Unobtainium stays a dark blue color with wispy hues of silver over it. If reduced the color does not show much sparkle but still has many vivid colors.

colors.name: Siriusly (multi-chromatic)
colors.manufacturer_description: Siriusly is the newest multi-chromatic color added to the Northstar palette. As a multi-chromatic color, this glass will shift depending on light source and kelvin temperature of the light bulb. This color will present teal greens, blues and even a bright purple! For best results, use a 2700K (kelvin) CFL bulb as well as using this glass in thicker applications. This glass contains a small amount of copper, use an oxidizing flame for best results.

colors.name: Steel Wool
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Steel Wool is a unique addition to the borosilicate color palette. It is a funky, bumpy color rod that turns smooth when melted. It has tons of sparkle and can be mixed with any color to add a sparkly shimmer to any piece. Steel Wool can be used in all applications with no cracking issues but use caution in deep encasement. We recommend using a neutral/oxidizing flame for Steel Wool. Use in the back of the flame and try a reducing flame to cut down on boiling. Try mixing Northstar Dark Cobalt with Northstar Steel Wool to get a very nice blue sparkle. A little hand mixing of Steel Wool will give you the color you desire.

colors.name: Sublime
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Sublime is a transparent iridescent signal light green. It is the most eye catching transparent borosilicate color in the palette. Sublime is atmospherically stable meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being affected. It is a member of the transparent family but it is saturated enough for thin blown work. It's most exciting application is as an overlay color. It looks amazing over Northstar Blue Caramel.

colors.name: Super Unobtainium
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Super Unobtainium is a dark blue sparkle. This color has lots of large crystals of metal on the surface. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is easily worked and can take a lot of heat. To keep the color most vibrant, work in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Try to avoid deep encasement as it may cause cracking. Please use Northstar Super Unobtainium with care and test before you make any thing that is expensive. Outside work seems to work just great with no problems. Try coating Northstar Super Unobtainium with Garnet or Pomegranate to achieve a brilliant ruby sparkle. Any transparent color coated over Super Unobtainium looks great. Northstar Super Unobtainium has lots more sparkle but does not have the Gun Metal surface of Northstar Unobtainium.

colors.name: Tan Silver Creek
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Tan Silver Creek is a yellowish cream color. It can yield rich purplish blue and creamy tan tones. When kept in a more oxidizing environment, you will get more of the blues and purples. If reduced, a silvery haze will appear on the surface. Northstar Tan Silver Creek is easy to work and can take a lot of heat which makes it a forgiving striking color. It can be stretched out and is good for blown work and sculpture. If you are looking for something even more intense, try Northstar Caramel or Northstar Silver Bullet.

colors.name: Timber
colors.manufacturer_description: Timber is the latest cadmium based forest green grass. In response to artists seeking a millefiori safe green, Northstar has responded with a new wonderful cadmium in addition to NS-150 Roswell. this glass is at the most saturated point without sacrificing the color of the glass. As a smooth working cadmium, this color may be slightly translucent when blown out of stretched thin. Let the heat sink in to avoid burning or boiling the glass. Another release from "Abes Vault" as a permanent addition to the NS Palette.

colors.name: Turbo Amethyst
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Turbo Amethyst is a smooth dark violet. This color is an intensified version of Northstar Dark Amethyst. This is a "what you see is what you get" color that works like butter. Use in a slightly neutral to oxidizing flame for best results. Turbo Amethyst is the violet version of Northstar Turbo Cobalt.

colors.name: Turbo Cobalt
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Turbo Cobalt is the most intense cobalt blue in the Northstar palette. It is great for stringer application and stretching out thin. If kept moderately thick, Turbo Cobalt is an excellent faux black. Because of it's intensity, Northstar Turbo Cobalt must be worked in a highly oxidizing flame to prevent graying. If however you are looking for a battleship grey, it can be achieved by working Turbo Cobalt in a heavily reducing flame. For a nice color combination, try layering Northstar Double Amber/Purple over Northstar Turbo Cobalt.

colors.name: Turquesa
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Turquesa is a more saturated version of Northstar Irrid and produces similar effects. When worked in an oxidizing flame, Turquesa yields more pronounced metallic blues. When reduced, deep sea greens result. Because it is more saturated than Irrid, Turquesa can be used for thinner blown work without thinning out. Try layering it over an opaque to yield new effects. Also, try reducing Turquesa, then encasing with clear.

colors.name: Unobtainium
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Unobtainium Borosilicate Glass Rods Northstar Unobtainium is a very dense gun metal blue with lots of sparkle. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is easily worked and can take a lot of heat. To keep the color most vibrant, work in a neutral to slightly oxidizing flame. Try to avoid deep encasement, it may cause cracking. Please use Northstar Unobtainium with care and test your application before making expensive pieces. Outside work seems to work just great with no problems. Try coating Unobtainium with Northstar Garent or Northstar Pomegranate to achieve a brilliant ruby sparkle. Any transparent color coated over Northstar Unobtainium looks great.

colors.name: Violet
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Violet is a light transparent red-ish purple. It is atmospherically stable meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being changed. It is also resistant to excessive heat, and can take a lot of abuse. Because Northstar Violet washes out when thinned most regard it as a color for sculpture only. However, like the other transparent colors, Violet is well suited as an overlay color. It looks great over Northstar Amber/Purple.

colors.name: Yellow
colors.manufacturer_description: If worked in an oxidizing environment, Northstar Yellow will yield a transparent golden yellow. If worked in a neutral to slightly reducing flame, Northstar Yellow will start to darken and opacify. Can be flame or kiln struck.

colors.name: Jade
colors.manufacturer_description: Jade is a saturated fully opaque plant green. It can be stretched out for stringer applications or thin blown work. With the reformulations that have been made it can be worked in a much hotter flame, but be careful not to overheat. Stay in a neutral to slightly oxidizing environment. As with the workability improvements, NS-011 Jade’s C.O.E. is far improved. It can be encased and used for inside-out applications. Be sure to run a thorough annealing schedule with encased NS-011 Jade. For a neat color effect, try layering a transparent striking color such as NS-003 Multi over NS-011 Jade.

colors.name: Light Cobalt
colors.manufacturer_description: Light Cobalt is the least saturated of the four shades of cobalt blue Northstar produces. Because it is the least intense it can be worked in any flame without altering the color.

colors.name: Blue Spruce
colors.manufacturer_description: A great opaque blue/green. Work in an oxidizing flame to keep the clarity. Reduce for interesting gray streaks that appear to be growth rings of a tree.

colors.name: Goldenrod
colors.manufacturer_description: A bright Intense Opaque gold color. Work slowly in a soft oxidizing flame to prevent boiling.

colors.name: Oregon Gray
colors.manufacturer_description: An atmospherically stable opal. Work slowly in a soft, unfocused flame to prevent surface scarring. Once melted in smooth, heat can be soaked in more rapidly.

colors.name: Light Oregon Gray
colors.manufacturer_description: An atmospherically stable opal. Work slowly in a soft, unfocused flame to prevent surface scarring. Once melted in smooth, heat can be soaked in more rapidly.

colors.name: Super Unobtainium
colors.manufacturer_description: Super Unobtainium is a dark blue sparkle. This color has lots of large crystals of metal on the surface. It is well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is easily worked and can take a lot of heat.

colors.name: Ruby
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Ruby Borosilicate Glass Rods Ruby is a medium intensity striking ruby. It is good for most blown work and can be worked relatively thin without washing out. For more information about working NS-007 Ruby refer to Northstar Newsletter 8 Find more information on the Ruby Family Page

colors.name: Amber Purple
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Amber Purple Borosilicate Glass Rods Amber/Purple: Of the striking colors in the borosilicate palette the Amber/purples are some of the most exciting. NS-013 is the first in a series of five Amber/Purple colors. This is an easy to use color and well suited for sculpture and moderately thin blown work. These Amber Purple Fats range in diameter from 10mm-14mm & have limited availablity.

colors.name: Star White
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Star White Borosilicate Glass Rods Star White is a creamy fully opaque white. It is an indispensable color in the palette for all applications. It is great for sculpture, stringers, blown work, and backings for all transparent colors. With several reformulations Star White has been turned into an easy color to work. It is atmospherically stable meaning it can be worked in any flame without the color being affected. To prevent any boiling issues, heat NS-054 Star White slowly and gently. Once the color is glowing it can take a lot of heat. The trick is patience with a soft flame!

colors.name: Lava
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Lava Borosilicate Glass Rods Lava is a bright intense opaque orange. It is very bright and well suited for stringer application and blown work. It is not terribly sensitive to flame chemistry but stay out of overly reducing flames. Lava however is heat sensitive so it must be worked carefully to prevent boiling. Encasing with clear is another method to shielding the color, but not necessary. Lava can be easily worked on the surface and will not boil or scar if worked carefully in a soft flame. A nice color effect to try is a layer of NS-007 Ruby over NS-064 Lava.

colors.name: Onyx
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Onyx Borosilicate Glass Rods Onyx is the smoothest most saturated black in the Norsthar palette. It is well suited for stringer applications and blown work. It is a green based black and in certain lights it has a slight green tint. Onyx can be worked hot and long without boiling issues and it is not sensitive to reduction. For best results keep it in a neutral flame. It looks great as a backing for NS-013 Amber/Purple and by itself. It is great for backing dichroic, gold, and silver fume.

colors.name: Blue Caramel
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Blue Caramel Borosilicate Glass Rods A rich buttery striking color. Keep it oxidized for hazy blues and greens. Reduce for the most scintillating mirror-like sheen. Blue Caramel is a lush high intensity silvery striking color. If worked in a super oxidizing flame it will yield smoky blues and greens. If reduced it provides the user with an extremely silvery tan color. If encased, the color turns to be a brilliant metallic green. It is easy to work and is well suited for stringer applications and blown work. Try layering NS-066 Sublime over the surface for a wonderful green effect!

colors.name: Roswell
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Roswell Borosilicate Glass Rods Roswell is a cadmium based green glass. Similar to the discontinued color NS-71 Avocado, this glass is a vibrant opaque green. Northstar has maximized the cadmium formula to be the brightest green saturation without sacrificing the color. The strongest attribute of this glass is its smooth working characteristics with a range of flame chemistry while retaining more density of color. Perfect for many applications from coil-potting, lined tubing, sculptural, stinger work, and best of all, deep encasements such as millefiori.

colors.name: Galaxy
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Galaxy Borosilicate Glass Rods alaxy is the first collaborative effort between Northstar Glass & Trautman Art Glass to produce a new color in rod. This color was formulated from the iconic NS-125 Jet Black base along with the amazing sparkle from the TAG Stardust family. Very durable & easy to use with a beautiful balance of dense black and heavy sparkle. Safe for encasement, though not recommended for millefiori or deep encasement. Use an oxidizing flame to prevent any gray streaks caused from reductive environment.

colors.name: Mystic Dream Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Mystic Dream Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Mystic Dream (produced 4-21-25) is light colored amber rod with a deep, almost opaque indigo/ violet strike, with hints of transparency. There are slight shifts toward maroon and blue depending on lighting. When worked in thicker or solid application, the color transitions into a dynamic, iridescent pattern featuring blues, greens, ambers, and purples similar to an oil slick. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Sunset Bloom Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Sunset Bloom Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Sunset Bloom (produced 4-29-25) is a very light amber, almost clear rod that strikes to a blue-gray with subtle tones of lavender, pale pink, and slightly hazey finish. When worked in thicker or solid application, you will get a more saturated and reactive purples, burgundy, and crimson red tones. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Ember Glow Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Ember Glow Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Ember Glow (produced 5-2-25) is an amber colored rod with a soft blue-gray strike similar to Sunset Bloom although with more magenta and light plum tones. When worked in thicker or solid application, this glass features more golden ambers, soft crimson reds, and tones of violet and turquoise blues. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Blossom Burst Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Blossom Burst Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Blossom Burst (produced 5-7-25) is a dark amber-orange rod that strikes grayish-blue and soft violet with a light refraction from the silver content similar to NS-041 Butterscotch . It has a soft, milky lavender finish that is slightly translucent. Also showing hints of reddish-orange, golden yellow, and pale blues and purples. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Violet Nebula Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Violet Nebula Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Violet Nebula (production 4-23-25) is a pale golden-yellow rod that develops deep, rich violet to indigo tones. When worked in thicker applications you achieve a vivid range of blues, greens, and purples like a cosmic, aurora, or psychedelic effect. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Oceanic Twilight Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Oceanic Twilight Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Oceanic Twilight (production 4-25-25) is a golden-amber rod that strikes deep oceanic blues with strong twilight-to-midnight purple tones. In thicker applications you can achieve cobalt-sapphire blue hues, along with swirls of purple, lavender, and deep magenta. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Golden Sunset Experimental
colors.manufacturer_description: Golden Sunset Experimental Northstar Glass Rod Exp. Golden Sunset (production 4-28-25) is an airy clear rod that has a lighter strike compared to all the other recent silver experiments. Similar to NS-009 Yellow , you can achieve rich honey yellows with fumey oranges and purples. Reducing flame or kiln strike to enhance vibrancy, allowing light to reflect beautifully off the surface. Transitional quality glass rods are a mix of Northstar’s standard First and Odd quality glass. For striking techniques, refer to our product info about The Amber Purple Family Abe's Vault Abe’s Vault” represents colors that are in the process of development. All colors will be sold in an experimental status until we determine if they will permanently become an addition to our palette. At that time, a release through our distributors will be made available. As the leader in colored borosilicate art glass manufacturing, Northstar Glassworks is committed to the pursuit of innovation in our industry.

colors.name: Canary
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Canary Borosilicate Glass Rods A bright Intense Opaque yellow. Work slowly in a cool oxidizing flame to prevent boiling. Canary is a bright intense opaque lemon yellow. It is eye catching and is well suited for stringer application, and blown work. It is not terribly sensitive to flame chemistry but stay out of overly reducing flames. Canary however is heat sensitive so it must be worked carefully to prevent boiling. Encasing with clear is another method to shielding the color, but not necessary. Canary can be easily worked on the surface and will not boil or scar if worked carefully in a soft flame. For a nice color effect layer NS-009 Yellow over NS-063 Canary.

colors.name: Purple Lilac
colors.manufacturer_description: Northstar Purple Lilac Borosilicate Glass Rods Purple lilac. Purple Lilac is a beautiful new color from Northstar Glassworks. The color is a nice purple/pink when used. The color rod before used looks opaque but after used it can yield many shades ranging from opaque to very nice transparent color We recommend using this color in any type of flame. For a more opaque color use a slightly reducing flame and for beautiful transparent color use an oxidizing flame. This color can be used in any application without problems as well. We consider this color to be a striking color so the more you anneal it the more opaque it will turn. Please remember that if you thin out the color too much you will not be able to bring it back to a nice opaque color.

colors.name: Cobalt Blue
colors.manufacturer_description: Can take a lot of heat and can be worked in a wide range of flame settings. Stay out of reducing flames to prevent dulling or gray streaking to occur.

colors.name: Light Blue Stardust
colors.manufacturer_description: 622074 TAG Light Blue Stardust Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Knight Rider
colors.manufacturer_description: 622037 TAG Knight Rider COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod

colors.name: Honey Badger
colors.manufacturer_description: 622052 TAG Honey Badger COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod TAG's Honey Badger is a nice, non-reactive transparent amber, perfect for honey bee themes. It's what you might call a WYSIWYG color, meaning What You See Is What You Get. Not atmosphere dependent but prefers to be worked in a cooler, softer flame. The high concentration of colorants in this glass can promote boiling if you work it too hot and too fast.

colors.name: Heavy XXenon
colors.manufacturer_description: 622047 TAG Heavy XXenon COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Satiny shimmering sparklers that shift greener in the kiln. Xenon is semi-translucent, and kiln-strikes to a nice dark pine green. Heavy XXenon is much more opaque. It can bloom with a bluish haze, especially where encased. The usual cautions for an adventurine color apply: limit with long hot garaging and encase with care. Heavy versions are best suited for surface work, but they can be encased and imploded with caution.

colors.name: Heavy Blue Stardust
colors.manufacturer_description: 622532 TAG Heavy Blue Stardust Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Green Stardust
colors.manufacturer_description: 622043 TAG Green Stardust COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Transparent adventurine with big, glittery dichro-like sparkles. Great for layering. Green is a light leaf shade. The usual cautions against long, hot garaging technically apply since this is an adventurine color, however it is highly stable on implosions. Heavy version is darker blue in color, and has higher density of sparkle.

colors.name: Blu-V
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG-064 Blu-V Rods Blu-V is a clear glass that fluoresces blue under a U.V. light source. Recommend to use an ultraviolet L.E.D. light with a 365Nm-395Nm range for the brightest blue glow. This is a stable glass and can be used in any type of flame.

colors.name: Black Jack
colors.manufacturer_description: 622005 TAG Black Jack COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Black Jack goes almost clear when hot, but self-strikes back through brown to near-black depending on how thick you use it. Black Jack likes an oxidizing flame, but does not reduce with gray streaks like most black boro colors. In the curls shown here, we had to get the glass right on top of the light to see the brown where it’s thinner. Black Jack is not suitable for thin stringer work where you want the stringers to look like a dense black, but it’s the perfect color for very specific things, like sculpting without the graying.

colors.name: Blue Blizzard
colors.manufacturer_description: 622013 TAG Blue Blizzard COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Blue Blizzard is a transparent to semi-opaque blue glass shot through with flecks of white glass "snow". Rough rods that smooth out in the flame. Blue Bliz should be worked in a neutral or oxidizing atmosphere to keep the white bits from boiling but it's a pretty flame tolerant glass. The "snow" of the Blizzard line resembles stone or old-fashioned speckled enamel-on-metal dishes.

colors.name: Dark Red Elvis (Black Elvis)
colors.manufacturer_description: 622002 TAG Dark Red Elvis (Black Elvis) COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod The darker version of the world's first self-striking boro. Dark Red Elvis is very saturated, and is a great choice for a red in thin stringers and thin-blown work. Dark Red Elvis self strikes as it cools but gets a little bit darker with kiln striking or flame striking. It will flame strike in a neutral to oxidizing atmosphere, at a slightly lower temperature than most rubies.

colors.name: Darth Badger
colors.manufacturer_description: 622053 TAG Darth Badger COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod The Darth Badger is a non-reactive reddish amber on "the dark side." A darker, more saturated version of the Honey Badger, the Darth is very nice in applications where you want to use an amber very thin and still show amber, or where you just want a darker and richer shade. It is highly saturated with colorants, however, and will boil if heated too fast. Non-reactive and works in any atmosphere, but prefers to be worked higher up in a bushy flame.

colors.name: Europa Star
colors.manufacturer_description: 622057 TAG Europa Star COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Like Io Star, this color is also named for a moon of Jupiter. Europa Star is the most silver-saturated of the 3 new "stars". Dense sparkles like the Io Star, but here the base tends more toward a dark pink/purple tone and and the strong striking nature of this color can hide the sparkles. Highly reactive! Like the other "stars", Europa Star is a flame striker that will deepen it's effects in the annealing cycle at 1050 F. Again, the usual precautions for an adventurine should be taken. Avoid long hot garaging and high temp. kiln strikes.

colors.name: Fade to Black
colors.manufacturer_description: 622058 TAG Fade to Black Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Heavy Blue Leprechaun
colors.manufacturer_description: 622030 TAG Heavy Blue Leprechaun COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod The first consistently implodable dense adventurine, Heavy Blue Leprechaun was a game changer! Paul Trautman's newer, more stable adventurine technology produces very densely saturated adventurines with large, dichro-like sparkles. Heavy Blue Leprechaun may be safely imploded into marbles, within reason. Not sensitive to flame atmosphere, but reduction should be avoided on any adventurines before implosion. Please limit long, hot garaging. This is also a good choice for mixing down with other colors to add rainbow sparkles, although it will leave traces of blue.

colors.name: Io Star
colors.manufacturer_description: 622056 TAG Io Star COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Amber/purple reactivity, with flash! A mix of the sable Stardust adventurine with reactive A/P: Io Star was cold worked and sculpted, quite sucessfully, by Etz (Merc's Minions) during field testing.

colors.name: Mega Mai Tai
colors.manufacturer_description: 622034 TAG Mega Mai Tai COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod That's the Mega Mai Tai - this one tends to give more purples and blues with the pinks, and strikes quickly in the flame.

colors.name: Mighty Moss
colors.manufacturer_description: 622032 TAG Mighty Moss COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Mighty Moss features Paul Trautman's newer adventurine technology, which has greatly improved the stability of glitter boro colors. This glass is a very densely saturated adventurine with large, dichro-like sparkles. Mighty Moss may be safely imploded in to marbles, within reason , meaning you should limit the time you "garage" your work. Do not go above 1050 F in the annealing cycle, and anneal as short a time as you can for the size of the piece. Not sensitive to flame atmosphere, but reduction should be avoided on adventurines before implosion.

colors.name: Orange Elvis
colors.manufacturer_description: 622051 TAG Orange Elvis COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Just as the name implies, Orange Elvis is a mix of the self-striking Red Elvis and the lightly reactive amber/purple type Yellow Elvis. This makes it an easy-strike color that will flame strike a lighter reddish-orange, or can be brought back to clear in the flame and then kiln strike for a darker reddish-orange look. Layer over clear to make a more true transparent orange. Oxy flames bring out brighter tones, reduction gives softer earthier colors due to the a/p component.

colors.name: Parallax (CFL Reactive)
colors.manufacturer_description: 622069 TAG Parallax Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Phaze (CFL Reactive)
colors.manufacturer_description: 622076 TAG Phaze Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Pink Lollypop
colors.manufacturer_description: 622059 TAG Pink Lollypop COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod This is the transparent version of the hugely popular Pink Cadillac. These rods have a better COE and are transparent to translucent, though they are "seeded" with tiny air bubbles.

colors.name: Purple Lollypop
colors.manufacturer_description: 622060 TAG Purple Lollypop COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod This is the transparent version of the hugely popular Wisteria. These rods have a better COE and are transparent to translucent, though they are "seeded" with tiny air bubbles.

colors.name: Purple Sable
colors.manufacturer_description: 622027 TAG Purple Sable COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Purple Sable is a very unusual amber/purple with a coffee-colored base and a light adventurine sparkle. The best reactions occur in a mid-range of temperatures, not too hot or too cool. Purple Sable shows different effects in different flame atmospheres - reductions, oxidation, and encasement. For a nice opalescence, trap the reduction effects under a layer of clear. Blues, purples, greens, ambers, and more can be produced on the surface of this glass.

colors.name: Red Blizzard
colors.manufacturer_description: 622015 TAG Red Blizzard COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Red Blizzard is a transparent to semi-opaque red glass shot through with flecks of white glass "snow". Rough rods that smooth out in the flame. Red Bliz should be worked in a neutral or oxidizing atmosphere to keep the white bits from boiling but it's a pretty flame tolerant glass. The "snow" of the Blizzard line resembles stone or old-fashioned speckled enamel-on-metal dishes.

colors.name: Red Elvis
colors.manufacturer_description: Red Elvis Borosilicate Glass Rods Red Elvis is an “easy striker” and self strikes as it cools but gets a little darker with flame striking or kiln striking. Red Elvis strikes in an oxidizing atmosphere, at a slightly lower temperature than most rubies. Work in a neutral to oxidizing flame.

colors.name: Shooting Star
colors.manufacturer_description: 622055 TAG Shooting Star COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Amber/purple reactivity, with flash! A mix of the sable Stardust adventurine with reactive A/P: Shooting Star is the lightest of the new colors, featuring a blue base.

colors.name: Sea Slyme
colors.manufacturer_description: Sea Slyme! A new shade for an old favorite. This is a very workable glass. a milky blue-green, it fills part of the spectrum between the new Blue slyme and regular Slyme. Like anything in the slyme family, finished work can range from opaque to translucent to transparent in the same piece from the same rod. The Sea Slyme has a milky strike you know and love but it's more teal than the original. It can thin to transparent very easily, especially when you put it over clear or you can use it thicker for more milky seafoam aqua green color. Reducing flame with the Sea Slyme: Like the rest of the slymes this glass is a little bit soft, meaning the COE is a little bit high, maybe a piont, point and a half. this is the same as Slyme, Pink Slyme, and all the opaque candy colors, Pink Caddy, Wisteria and Kiwi.

colors.name: Solar Flare
colors.manufacturer_description: 622072 TAG Lemon Solar Flare Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Sparky
colors.manufacturer_description: 622049 TAG Sparky COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Sparky is fairly opaque and is made up of silver sparkles. You can work it from the rod without re-mixing, or you can mix it down with any color to add bling. Sparky has proven to be stable and implodable. Rough textured rods smooth out beautifully in the flame. Great for layering.

colors.name: Sunset Slyme (CFL Reactive)
colors.manufacturer_description: 622070 TAG Sunset Slyme Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Syzygy (CFL Reactive)
colors.manufacturer_description: 622066 TAG Syzygy Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: Tropical Green Borosilicate
colors.manufacturer_description: 622068 TAG Tropical Green Borosilicate Glass Rods.

colors.name: TurboCo
colors.manufacturer_description: 622007 TAG TurboCo COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod TurboCo is a highly saturated cobalt. Use thick as a black, or thinner as a blue. Work TurboCo in a oxidizing flame atmosphere. Reducing may cause grey streaks.

colors.name: Dwarf White
colors.manufacturer_description: 622035 Dwarf White COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod A very smooth and creamy new opaque white, made from scratch. Resists boiling once brought up to temperature, and has a fine, smooth texture, especially compared to our Stag and Jawbone. Dwarf White has been described as “docile and dense,” and works like “buttah.” Not sensitive to atmosphere.

colors.name: Blue Slyme
colors.manufacturer_description: Unlike the regular Slyme, the Blue Slyme keeps more of its color under clear encasement. But the biggest difference between the new Blue Slyme and regular green Slyme is the flame -- you will want to use a bushy NEUTRAL flame instead of a lot of reduction. Like most colors in the Slyme family, this glass is a little bit soft, meaning the COE is a little bit high, maybe a point, point and a half. This is the same as Slyme, Dense Slyme 3, Satin Slyme and Pink Slyme, and all the opaque candy colors, Pink Caddy, Wisteria and Kiwi.

colors.name: Slyme
colors.manufacturer_description: Ah, Slyme. Ectoplasmic! One of the most unusual colors in the boro palette, Slyme can range from transparent to translucent to a milky semi-opaque, depending on how you work it. Work cooler to keep Slyme more opaque, with a soft reducing flame. Goes transparent under higher heat, but can develop a ghostly milky green haze.

colors.name: Double Mai Tai
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG Double Mai Tai COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Double Mai Tai is a member of the amber/purple family, but with less amber and more pinks and purples. It can gain more color in the kiln, but it strikes well in the flame, with lots of pink — especially over a base of white. Double Mai Tai is hard to over-strike.

colors.name: Pink Cadillac
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG Pink Cadillac COE 33 Borosilicate Trautman Art Glass Rod Pink Cadillac is a opaque and dense pink that prefers a soft, enveloping flame. While it is not really boily, they do have some air in them which can mimic boil, especially when heated hard and fast. For those of you on sharp and forceful torches in particular we suggest warming in the upper flame before working slowly and allowing the occasional larger air bubbles to escape as you work.

colors.name: Mai Tai Pink
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG Mai Tai Pink Rods Mai Tai Pink is colorless in the rod, but it changes dramatically in the kiln after being flame worked! Flame strikes to barely amber yellow, but it’s designed to change considerably during longer annealing at 1050. May be kilned repeatedly for more color, or ramped up to 1150 to speed the strike. Can also be un-struck in the flame after the kiln cycle for interesting color-fade effects. It is virtually impossible to over-strike this color. Burn off haze for more pinks or leave the haze for more purple effects.

colors.name: Pink Slyme
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG Pink Slyme Rods Pink Slyme strikes milky to semi-opaque depending on how you work it. Pink Slyme does not need as much reduction as our other Slymes, and is a pink-purple with the same density and milk-strike as a regular green Slyme.

colors.name: Dark Blue Slyme
colors.manufacturer_description: TAG Dark Blue Slyme Rods Dark Blue Slyme has everything you know and love about a Slyme: finished work can range from opaque to translucent to transparent in the same piece from the same rod of color. You can bring out a milky strike that gives visual depth, and you can pull out rich color where the strike is burned away.
